Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Evaluating Technological Innovation in Agriculture and Food Security

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Scientists warn that food security will only become more challenged in the coming decades as environmental shocks intensify and agriculture grows increasingly vulnerable to disruption. Amid a new sense of urgency regarding environmental change and food production, policymakers are deciding how to allocate development aid to improve food systems under the banner of climate-smart agriculture (CSA). CSA aims to be an experimental and data-driven approach, with a focus on introducing new technologies, improved and transgenic seeds and novel farming techniques among small-scale farmers to mitigate the effects of rapid environmental change more efficiently. The United States is an early adopter of the climate-smart concept since 2010 but has only recently started to direct official development aid toward expressly climate-smart agricultural (CSA) programs elsewhere, in conjunction with international organizations, philanthropic foundations, and multinational corporate partners. To date, the technological and relational content of climate-smart agriculture in practice has received little in-depth scholarly investigation. Both academics and practitioners of development puzzle over what climate resilience actually entails and how its success can be achieved and measured. This study, which trains a graduate student in methods of rigorous, empirical data collection and analysis, explores the relationship between climate-smart agriculture and practices related to food security. Further, this project will build capacity and scientific infrastructure through international scientific cooperation, and enhance public scientific understanding by broadly disseminating findings to organizations engaged in issues related to agricultural development and food security.

Serena Stein, under the supervision of Dr. Joao Biehl of Princeton University, will investigate how agricultural aid is remade with experimental, relational, and ethical implications for smallholder farmers, through a grounded study of three unfolding climate smart projects in Mozambique in southeastern Africa. Mozambique is an appropriate site for assessing climate-smart agriculture in practice. The high volume of development aid invested historically and currently, especially in the area of sustainable development, makes it an ideal laboratory for evaluating climate-smart agriculture longitudinally. Climate-smart commitments take place via bilateral aid partnerships with traditional donors such as the United States, as well as emerging donors like Brazil, and private corporations. Using ethnographic methods of participant-observation and interviews with farmer beneficiaries and development practitioners, the researchers will examine how development discourse, technology transfer and farming practice is reconfigured when agricultural aid is mobilized around the climate-smart paradigm. Of particular interest are the ways that women farmers respond to these initiatives, and the local perceptions and lived experiences of environmental change, land rights and food security that emerge in the context of these interventions.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Serena Stein has completed research for her dissertation, “Kindred Frontiers: Experiments in Aid, Agribusiness, and Conviviality in Mozambique” supported by the NSF Dissertation Improvement Grant. During the funding period, she spent 12 months in northern Mozambique working with international and public-private partnerships in seed breeding and agricultural technology development and transfer to farmers, while also working with small-scale farmer cooperatives and associations following the adoption and use of technologies amid increasing stressors to farming under climate change.

As an anthropologist of technology, environment, and gender in international development, Stein was interested in understanding how an emerging paradigm of Climate-Smart Agriculture potentially redefines agricultural development policy approaches to technology; how state and foreign plant scientists participate in seed technology development; how international development and philanthropic organizations  allocate funds to seed breeding and relative contributions of public agencies and corporate actors; and how farmers participate, adopt, and utilize seed technologies in everyday farming activities. She specifically focused on women farmers' participation in technology transfer programs with consequences for land tenure, household divisions of labor, and food security. 

As a participant observer,  Stein accomplished the goal of her research and has begun communicating findings in scholarly presentations as well as academic and public scholarship. The data Stein collected while observing the day to day exchanges, trainings, and use of climate-smart agricultural initiatives in farming is the foundation for an argument she is constructing about the gendered exclusion of women farmers from commercial farming domains and the democratization of technology. She also elaborates arguments concerning how farmers innovate in their utilization of technologies in daily practice, which redefines seeds into active and shapable as opposed to received and immutable technologies. Stein's work has the potential to impact development praxis beyond the dissertation as she communicates concerns with increasing participatory seed breeding programming and expanding public research capacities for plant science in African countries as international development agendas are rapidaly reshaped due to the influx of climate adaptation and mitigation funding. 

Stein’s research and earlier investigations in Brazil and Mozambique form the basis of her dissertation to be completed in 2020. The study makes an important contribution to Science and Technology Studies and intersections with Agrarian Studies and Environmental Anthropology as it asserts how ideas of progress, politics of gender and inequality, and anticipations of climate change are central to scientific practice and circulations of new technologies.
